_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. 

Note: This summary includes additional information not included in the RMP Submit to assist California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant. Turlock South Processing Plant management, process operators, technicians, contractors plus all involved and affected employees towards safe operation. In addition, some of the detail provided within this summary was excluded from the submitted RMP as current public access to this detail could expose the facility and personnel to terrorist or criminal activity.

The covered process does not meet the requirements of Program 1. It is subject to OSHA's PSM standard.  Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance. 

This program was updated in mid-2018 as part of the 5-year program update requirement for both the State and Federal resubmittal. 

The following areas are addressed in this summary:

1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source
2.	The stationary source and regulated substances handled
3.	The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures 
4.	The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
5.	The five-year accident history
6.	The emergency response program
7.	Planned changes to improve safety

A-1	 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant is committed to complying with all the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental rele

ases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.

State regulations require reporting when there is an accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental release of ammonia.  California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.

All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedures that may prevent future incidents.

Any release of more than 25 ppm may result in immediately shutting down the ammonia systems depending on the location of the release. The Maintenance Manager and Director of Regulatory Compliance are to be called if not on site for support.  Releases less than 25 ppm shall result in immediately calling the Maintenance Manager, if not on site, for instructions.

The facility utilizes inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment on an ongoing basis and prior to changes. These procedures identify potential sources of release, administrative and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite personnel, refrigeration experts, and certified refrigeration contractors as required, review the equipment and administrative procedures and engineering controls.

A-2	STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant facility provides production, product cooling, and short-term storage of dairy products. The covered process (engine room) is operated year-round 24/7.

The faci

ors, condensers, evaporators, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief/vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps etc.

See the Prevention Program Element 5 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Refrigeration Office and on APSM website.

Management of Change
The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even "replacement in kind") be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before startup and trained in the proper procedures.

See the Prevention Program Element 6 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained electronically and/or on APSM website.

Pre-Startup Safety Review
Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.

See the Prevention Program Element 7 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained with the management of change and on APSM website.

Compliance Audits
To ensure that all the other 12 areas of PSM program are followed, the company requires compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years.

See the Prevention Program Element 8 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed on APSM website.

Incident Investigation
An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of ammonia

lity is in an industrial area of Stanislaus County on a contiguous property. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the refrigeration system. The total ammonia inventory in the process at 16,600 lbs. exceeds the Federal and State thresholds.

The refrigeration system is a direct, mechanical closed loop refrigeration system. The facility was built in 1988 and then expanded in 1996 and again in 2013.

The ammonia equipment is in a machinery room (engine room), outside and in the refrigerated rooms.

A-3 	HAZARD ASSESSMENT

The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s) include administrative controls and mitigation measures. The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe. 

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. In addition, Process 1 components are separated by walls and distance. Furthermore, as the refrigerant escapes pressure will decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.

The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.

A-4	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant's Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM Manual. The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant's Prevention Program are briefly described below:
1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information. (Addressed under the Pr

ocess Safety Information Element)

2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system.  The evaluation considers several potential problems including mechanical problems, human errors, and external events.  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant management.  (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Mechanical Integrity Elements)

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Mechanical Integrity, and Incident Investigation Elements) 

4) Certification of refrigeration operators (in-house and refrigeration contractor employees) to safely operate the refrigeration system.  California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant and/or the refrigeration contractor certifies individuals following completion of operator training.  Finally, California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant and the contractor shall confirm the individual's ability to apply what they have learned.  (Addressed under Training and Contractor Elements)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation El

ement)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant's Management of Change Procedure. 
If a mechanical change is required and for maintenance contracts, California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history through ISNetworld. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other "Hot Work" occurs close to the refrigeration system, a California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire. 

Following completion of a mechanical change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be charged or started. (These areas are addressed under Management of Change, Contractor Qualifications, Hot Work Permit, and Pre Start-up Safety Review Elements)

7) Verification of California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant's compliance with the RMP/PSM program.  This self-audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the prevention program has been implemented and properly documented by California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant personnel.  California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant has established a procedure to address any shortcomings which the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit element)   

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant's Injury and Illness Prevention Program)

INJURY AND ILLINESS/ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

This facility follows the EPA's 40CFR68 Risk Management Plan and OSHA's 29CFR1910.119 Process Sa

fety Management Program.  In addition, the plan satisfies the State of California's Injury and Illness Prevention Program requirements CCR Title 8, 3203.

In California, every employer is required by law to provide a safe and healthy workplace to his/her employees. In accordance with the California Code of Regulations, California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant has an effective written Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP). 

The IIPP is a written plan that covers the following elements:

 	Management commitment/assignment of responsibilities 
 	Safety communications system with employees 
 	System for assuring employee compliance with safe work practices 
 	Scheduled inspections/evaluation system 
 	Accident investigation 
 	Procedures for correcting unsafe/unhealthy conditions 
 	Safety and health training and instruction 
 	Recordkeeping and documentation 
 	
The IIPP includes procedures that California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant personnel must put into practice. It is both the employer's and employee's responsibility to control potential workplace hazards and correct hazardous conditions or practices as they occur or are recognized. The program includes a system for personnel to communicate with management on matters relating to occupational safety and health, including provisions designed to encourage employees to inform management of hazards at the worksite without fear of reprisal.
The safety communications system, one of the elements of the IIPP, is readily available and understandable to all affected employees.
 
The safety communication system includes:

 	Meetings 
 	Training programs 
 	Postings 
 	Written communications 
 	A system for anonymous notification by employees about hazards 
 	Labor/management safety and health committees 
 	Safety meetings
 	
In addition to the above, during construction the IIPP requires that managers conduct safety meetings with their crews to emphasize safety. Managers also hold periodi

c meetings to discuss safety problems and accidents that have occurred.

The completed IIPP is filed and maintained in the EHS Manager's files on the Company server.

The documents and records are kept as identified in each element of the program for the current year and then archived.

The following identifies the practices and procedures for:

   Process Safety Information
   Process Hazard Analysis
   Operating Procedures
   Training
   Mechanical Integrity
   Management of Change
   Prestart-up Review
   Compliance Audits
   Incident Investigations
   Employee Participation
   Hot Works
   Contractors

Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information includes a wide variety of books, manuals, and process information. These are available to employees that operate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as SDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, IIAR safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, ventilation system design, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipment specifications, electrical classifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.

See the Prevention Program Element 1 for the complete information
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained on APSM website

Process Hazard Analysis
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the "What-if" checklist.  This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, external events and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results

of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.

See Element 2 of the Prevention Program for the complete guidelines
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained electronically and on APSM website

Technical Operating Specifications and Standard Operating Procedures
The Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) and Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) are provided for each compressor, condenser, ammonia vessel, oil pot, and evaporator etc. Topics include general information such items as;

¿	Objectives 
¿	Special hazards 
¿	Location 
¿	Safety equipment needed 
¿	P&ID's and Block Flow Diagrams
¿	Technical operating specifications, 
¿	Step-by-step procedures
¿	Specific warnings & PPE 

The SOPs cover different phases of operations such as: initial startup; normal operation, temporary and emergency operations; emergency shutdowns; and startup following a shutdown. Various other safety programs and procedures are included.

See the Prevention Program Element 3 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are maintained in a binder in the engine room and on APSM website

Training
All employees who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the SDS, routine refrigeration system operation, emergency refrigeration system operation, emergency and normal refrigeration safety practices, and the individual's role in the emergency response plan or action plan.

See the Prevention Program Element 4 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Safety and Training Manager's Office, ISNetworld for contractors, and/or on APSM website.

Mechanical Integrity
The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition.   Inspections, and ongoing maintenance based on industry standards are performed on all compress

. The purpose is to gain information that could prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency action plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated promptly using a trained team. The findings and recommendations will be studied, and appropriate corrective action taken.
See the Prevention Program Element 9 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed electronically and maintained on APSM website.

Employee Participation
The Employee Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community.  As a rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause accidents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the PSM Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phase of the PSM program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.

See the Prevention Program Element 10 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Safety & Training Manager's Office and on APSM website.

Hot Work and Safe Work Practices
This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done outside the shop area. Maintenance reviews and issues permits to ensure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operation and the fire watch is completed.

See the Prevention Program Element 11 for the c

omplete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Safety & Training Manager's Office.

Contractors and Contractor Qualifications
This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process or the system. The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the ammonia process, that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids. 

See the Prevention Program Element 12 for the complete guidelines. 
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained through ISNetworld.

A-5	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There were no reportable ammonia releases that meet the reporting regulation at the California Dairies, Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant during the last 5 years. 

A-6	EMERGENCY RESPONSE/ACTION PROGRAM

California Dairies, Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Action Plan for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 

Facility personnel should coordinate with responding outside agencies such as Turlock Fire.  The facility has coordinated with outside parties through drills.  Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency. In addition, Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities capabilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and/or a chemical release.

Detailed plans have been developed to assist responders and company personnel.  All areas (zones) can be brought under control within 20 minutes of any ammonia emergency or breakdown if personnel/contractors are on site.  Small releases can be brought under control immedi

ately.  

The plan for all releases is to gain access to the shut down valves and controls for the system with the release.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area the entire ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate.  The appropriate shut down switches and controls are identified at the facility.  

The facility will assist outside agencies on the facility during large releases of hazardous chemicals, as personnel do not enter IDLH atmospheres.  All personnel will evacuate to the meeting areas and be accounted for.

A-7	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns.  The prevention program has been updated because of recent addition / changes of equipment.  A PHA study was conducted at California Dairies Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant and the study team made recommendations for additional safety.

In 2023, the process hazard analysis was completed, new recommendations were proposed as part of the study. California Dairies, Inc. Turlock South Processing Plant continues to implement recommendations from the mechanical integrity inspection which will help to ensure the safe operation of the covered process equipment.  The facility also continues to implement recommendations from compliance audits which helps ensure the facility is within the program guidelines and any recommendations from the safety committee.

Replace open drive ammonia pump. Complete the installation/replacement of the new hermetic pump.
Verify Palletizing and Butter Cooler Room air unit control locations and functionality. Insert this information into the Process Safety Information Element. (PSI).
Verify Main Control Syst

ems capabilities and functionality. Insert this information into the Process Safety Information Element.
Ongoing recommendation. Continue inviting fire and county hazmat to annual meetings, training, and drills.
